Saturday I was flipping channels and landed on CNN. It seemed like they were just blatanly campaigning for Kerry. There was a latina woman being interviewed. She was being asked questions like "Why do you think Kerry has earned the confidence of latinos in America" 
 "Well, it's obvious when you look at the facts..."
 
 Then, out of curiosity, I flipped right to FoxNews and wouldn't you believe there was a black man being interviewed. "Why do you think Bush has earned the black vote?" 
 "Well ,when you look at the facts..."
 
 Then I flipped a couple up to Dennis Miller. "So, how'd Bush do at the NUL?" "Oh, amazingly well...."
 
 Then I flipped to Headline News showing a clip of Bush saying only "the republican party has a lot of work to do" Well, Bush 'tried' at least at the NUL, was the gist.
 
 I don't know, but I think this is the most blatant I've seen this sort of thing. Usually, it's much more subtle and if you're not looking for it you can miss the bias, which is a good thing.
 
 Well, my question is, does this make you sick? Do you feel informed by the news or grimy just for watching it? How can we trust what the news says when they are so blatantly and unashamedly biased? I know this isn't a new thing, but how can you feel confident in the voting booth when all you've heard are 2 sides, never an outside perspective?

That's exactly why I never watch the tv news. There may be a channel out there that really is fair and balanced, but I don't know which one it is.
 
 When I want to research a topic, I generally go to news.google.com. Type in a headline and you get links to hundreds of articles. Some liberal, some conservative, some local, some foreign. It helps to get a fuller picture of what's happening.
